FY 20-21.actionsImplemented1:
(a) Modeling
(i) Development of a convolutional neural network (CNN) for the classification of imagery from an airborne cloud particle imager (CPI) probe captured during intensive operating periods (IOPs) for NOAA, DOE, NASA, and NSF. These particles are classified according to particle habit, type, and phase, and will aid in profiling the microphysics of the systems within which they were captured. A database of these images is being established for persistent use. This project is funded by the Department of Energy (DOE, PI: Sulia).

(ii) Development of a multi-class classification NN for the prediction of solar irradiance 1-hr in the future, utilizing 5-min data reported by the NY State Mesonet (NYSM). Prediction of solar irradiance will serve as input to a ML model used to prediction PV generation and load on the solar component of utility grids. This project is funded by NYSERDA, in collaboration with Electrical Distribution Design (NYSERDA/EDD, PIs: Bassill/Sulia).

(iii) A convolutional neural network is being developed for the identification of cloud type using NYSM camera images. Additional projects beginning with AI2ES REU summer program will also classify images to identify precipitation and level of visibility. (NSF, PIs: Thorncroft, Sulia, Bassill, Brotzge)
 
(b) Smart adaptive scientific visualization projects:
(i)	extreme wind forecasts (PI: Freedman, funding: NYSERDA, customer: ConEd),
(ii)	air quality forecast and real-time display (PI: Lu, funding: NYSERDA, customer: DEC),
(iii)	integrated systems model for load, PV, and outage forecasts (PI: Sulia/Bassill/Electrical Distribution Design, funding: NYSERDA, customer: ORU & CHGE). These are interactive browser-based software tools that update at a specified rate, adapting display of real-time observation/model data, with enhanced user activity, and
(iv)	mobile application for the NYSM (iOS and Android)
 
(c) Hardware Development
The hardware resources in xCITE have been optimized for the development of ML algorithms as well as persistent background activity and scientific visualization. SLURM has been installed to allow for account management and job scheduling, and job submission via docker containers to allow for containerized development environments. These tasks are critical for the efficient AI development.
FY 20-21.actionsImplemented2:
Dr Schwab and his group have had a busy year graduating students, publishing work and seeking new funds. Regular group meetings have taken place as planned.

Dr. Lance led an NSF funded workshop July-Nov 2020 with a prestigious international community to discuss research objectives and implementation strategies for a network of high elevation atmospheric research observatories within the continental U.S. to address scientific questions regarding greenhouse gases, reactive trace gases, aerosols, clouds and precipitation. The workshop was designed around obtaining information to prepare a proposal for a 5-year NSF mid-scale research infrastructure grant, which are solicited every two years.  The purpose of this effort is to kickstart a major reinvestment in the WFM infrastructure and instrumentation, and enhance national and international collaboration. Two initial attempts for this research support have been unsuccessful but we intend to try again in ~1.5 years.
50th Anniversary: Plans continue for the 50th Anniversary celebrations and related activities, postponed last year due to COVID. In conjunction with the 50th anniversary of the summit observatory we continue to plan for major upgrades of our electrical systems as well as a roof replacement project underway. To celebrate the anniversary we have planned the following so far:
•	There will be a 50th anniversary presentation as part of the Summer Falconer Science and Natural History lecture series recounting the construction, recent upgrades as well as the environmental monitoring and research projects taking place at the site.
•	We are planning to hold a student symposium and banquet to commemorate the anniversary as conditions allow; ideally in Fall 2021.
•	We will create the planned whitepaper before the symposium.

The EIP Search committee met frequently during this period. We were pleased to have 46 qualified applicants for this search. A final recommendation is expected by the end of June or beginning of July with plans for a Fall Semester start.
FY 20-21.actionsImplemented3:
(a) Solar
Funded research is the main action item, and objectives were met: two contracts secured since a year ago: $315k from Clean Power Research and $75k from Natural Resource Canada. Currently in the process of extending the Clean Power Research contract for an additional $250k.

On the research visibility front Dr Perez continued participation as a US expert in the International Energy Agency PV Power Systems Program as leader of a new activity of firm renewable power generation. He accepted the role of solar resource theme chair for the upcoming Solar World Congress and served on the board of the United Solar Energy Supporters in quality of expert to promote the most effective deployment of large scale solar.

Dr Perez taught a Renewable Energy Graduate course in collaboration with Dr Freedman, served on 3 international PhD Committees (U. Rome, U. Paris, and U. Reunion), and made several public presentations to regional and international organizations (latest in date is a webinar at Rome University last week).  

(b) Wind

Funded research objectives have been met. 
Department of Energy (DOE) contract was achieved to develop a flux measurement system for deployment on floating (buoy-based) platforms in tandem with a wind profiling lidar. This will support the establishment of fundamental measurements (marine boundary layer fluxes and profiles) currently not available in ocean environments with a focus on offshore wind energy applications (resource assessment and forecasting). Summer deployments for testing at Lake George (collaboration with RPI and IBM), Oneida Lake (collaboration with Cornell University), and Seneca Lake (collaboration with Hobart and William Smith Colleges).

Dr Freedman serves as co-chair of the American Meteorological Society’s (AMS) Renewable Energy Committee; co-chair of the 12th Conference on Weather, Climate, and the New Energy Economy (January 2021; also upcoming 13th Conference in January 2022); co-chair of the AMS’s Washington Forum (April 2021),  and made several public presentations to regional, national, and international organizations (AMS, American Wind Energy Association).
(c) Grid Resiliency
In addition, ASRC continues to make great strides into seeking resources to carry out research in the more general area of Grid Resiliency (that often includes accounting for Renewable Energy). We collaborated with UConn to achieve a significant NYSERDA grant that takes advantage of mesonet data for outage prediction and we also achieved an NSF planning grant that will create a consortium of private companies to work with us on grid resiliency.
FY 20-21.actionsImplemented4: ASRC faculty, staff, and students in this portfolio have maintained regular group meetings and active research activities (as can be seen from extensive publications), despite of the ongoing pandemic. Several faculty members had a strategic discussions on potential collaboration with DOE, NOAA, and NCAR. A number of proposals have been submitted and some of proposals have been awarded.
FY 20-21.actionsImplemented5:
(a) DOE project (Miller/Freedman)
This is in progress involving summer field campaigns using lab pontoon boat and 3D scanning lidar on Upstate NY lakes:
•	Lake George - collaboration with RPI Darren FreshWater Institute. We will be based at the Institute in Bolton Landing
•	Seneca Lake - collaboration with Hobart William Smith. We will utilize their lake facilitities as a base for our campaign, and lodge in one of their college owned dorms/houses
•	Lake Oneida - collaboration with Cornell. We will base the campaign at Shackleton Point Research Station and will stay in dormitories at the station. 
(b) NYSERDA project (Miller/Lu)
•	Collaboration with DEC - we will co-locate our low-cost air quality sensor packages at the DEC site at Queens college for calibration
•	Kindwell, Inc. - small company in Delaware, MD who will be making 50 custom low-cost sensor packages that we will deploy at 37 NYSM/NYCM sites as well as at Queens college DEC site
(c) NSF Mid-Scale RI-2 Consortium submission (Freedman/Thorncroft/Brotzge)
•	NSF Mid-scale RI-2 Consortium: Establishment of a coastal atmospheric boundary layer network (CABLnet); co-PI  (lead PI Ruben Delgado, University of Maryland, Baltimore County) on large project ($70M) to establish a coastal profiling network in the US and Caribbean.

FY 20-21.changes2: Hiring was delayed due to COVID but is expected to be completed this summer.
FY 20-21.changes3: No change planned, except retirement that may be an issue to deal with in the next 15-18 months. Also we plan to include “Grid Resiliency” under this heading.
FY 20-21.changes4: In the next year after we move into ETEC, we expect more interactions and collaborations among faculty, staff, and students in different research groups.
FY 20-21.changes5: Graduate student recruitment was unsuccessful. In light of these rejections we are discussing options and next steps for recruiting grad students or postdocs.

FY 20-21.mission: The mission of the New York State Mesonet (NYSM) is to serve the state of New York by providing the best meteorological data, the best products, and the best services possible with the goal of saving lives and property while building a smart weather economy. At its core, the NYSM is a highly dedicated, cross-disciplinary team aspiring to set the worldwide standard of excellence for data quality. With its unique focus on research to operations, preventive maintenance, and state-of-the-art quality control efforts, the NYSM utilizes these high quality weather data to create end products designed to improve forecast accuracy, reduce uncertainty, and mitigate harm.
FY 20-21.vision: The vision of the New York State Mesonet is to become a national center, collaborating with government, academic, and commercial partners, to educate and solve real-world problems in agriculture, emergency management, energy, public health, and transportation, improving the well being and livelihood for all.
FY 20-21.annualBudget:
Approximately $1M.  Actual need is ~ $2.5M.
Money received is a mix of federal money from the National Mesonet Program (via private contractor), direct funds from research grants, and university support.
FY 20-21.listOfCenter: 1. J. Brotzge, J. Wang, C. Thorncroft, E. Joseph, N. Bain, N. Bassill, N. Farruggio, J. Freedman, K. Hemker, D. Johnston, E. Kane, S. McKim, S. Miller, J. Minder, P. Naples, S. Perez, J. J. Schwab, M. J. Schwab, and J. Sicker, 2020: A Technical Overview of the New York State Mesonet Standard Network, J. Atmos. Oceanic Technol., 1-48.
FY 20-21.topAchievements1: Design and deployment of a $1M, 17-station urban network across New York City for Consolidated Edison, Inc.  These data are used for monitoring climate and for use in short-term utility operations.
FY 20-21.topAchievements2: Design and deployment of a 12-station solar measurement network across the Hudson River Valley in collaboration with NYSERDA and regional utilities.  These data will be used to optimize data usage by utilities for integration of renewable solar energy production.
FY 20-21.topAchievements3: Operate and maintain 180+ station New York State Mesonet with an uptime of > 99%. During 2020-2021, the NYSM has incorporated its own Calibration Laboratory, which is now fully functional.
FY 20-21.topAchievements4: Secured $400K in federal funding for the NYSM National Profiler Network for the 2020-2021 fiscal year.  The NYSM is establishing a national testbed for the development, testing, and evaluation of ground-based vertical profiling technologies.
FY 20-21.topAchievements5: The NYSM, in collaboration with university and external partners, submitted 14 proposals during the 2020-2021 fiscal year. These were submitted to NSF, NASA, NIH, DOE, and NOAA.
FY 20-21.goal1: Operate and maintain all 222 statewide weather stations of the NYS Mesonet during 2020 - 2021 with a combined 97.5%+ uptime.
FY 20-21.goal2: To lead and support grant sponsored research of at least $1 million during the 2020-2021 season.
FY 20-21.goal3: Expand NYS Mesonet communications through increased peer-reviewed publications and media.
FY 20-21.actions1: The above goal was accomplished.  The NYSM continues to maintain its 180 stations, plus additional collaborative networks, including the 12-station roadside network, 12-station solar network, 17-station urban network, and 1 DOT wind site. The NYSM achieved 99%+ uptime during the year period.
FY 20-21.actions2: Achieved.  The NYSM realized > $1M in external project research.  Specifically, the NYSM collaborated with Consolidated Edison, Inc. to design and deploy a 17-station urban weather network across NYC.
FY 20-21.actions3: The NYSM completed its first overview paper with publication of a description of its network in a peer-reviewed journal.  Additional papers were submitted for review.
FY 20-21.metrics1: The NYSM achieved 99% uptime during the year.
FY 20-21.metrics2: The NYSM achieved > $1M in external projects.
FY 20-21.metrics3: The NYSM completed its first journal publication, with 3 additional papers written and either submitted for review or are ready for submission.
FY 20-21.timeframe1: The NYSM achieved 99%+ uptime during the 01/01/20 - 12/31/20 period.  The NYSM has continued to record 99%+ during 2021.
FY 20-21.timeframe2: The NYSM achieved > $1M in external projects between June 2020 and present.
FY 20-21.timeframe3: The papers were published and/or submitted for review since June 2020.
FY 20-21.actionsImplemented1: To continue to achieve this level of performance, the NYSM has developed its own Calibration Laboratory.  This new Cal Lab allows the NYSM to calibrate its own sensors, providing a more cost-effective and faster turnaround on sensor calibrations and repairs.
FY 20-21.actionsImplemented3: Set aside time for publication of results.  Continue to write and submit additional papers for publication.
FY 20-21.otherThoughtsToGrowResearch: NYSM is leading the development of a national Profiling Testbed, and associated with that, is a co-PI on two large nationally-led proposals.  Many opportunities to expand collaborations across the transportation, health, agriculture, and energy sectors.
FY 20-21.bigChallenges: The NYSM requires publicly funded financial support, and so far, has received no support from NYS.  The NYSM supports many state agencies, and so the lack of financial support from the state has severely limited what NYSM has been able to accomplish.
FY 20-21.resourceNeeds: The NYSM has operated on a budget of ~ $1M, but requires an annual budget of ~$2.5M.  The NYSM needs several additional staff in order to expand its collaborations with external partners.
FY 20-21.strategicSuggestions: The NYSM has weather operations in every county and borough across New York State.  Local political leaders could be approached to support those operations within their districts.  Furthermore, data generated from these stations can be made available to local schools, if support could be obtained to do so.

FY 21-22.mission: The mission of the New York State Mesonet (NYSM) is to serve the state of New York by providing the best meteorological data, the best products, and the best services possible with the goal of saving lives and property while building a smart weather economy. At its core, the NYSM is a highly dedicated, cross-disciplinary team aspiring to set the worldwide standard of excellence for data quality. With its unique focus on research to operations, preventive maintenance, and state-of-the-art quality control efforts, the NYSM utilizes these high quality weather data to create end products designed to improve forecast accuracy, reduce uncertainty, and mitigate harm.
FY 21-22.vision: The vision of the New York State Mesonet is to become a national center, collaborating with government, academic, and commercial partners, to educate and solve real-world problems in agriculture, emergency management, energy, public health, and transportation, improving the well being and livelihood for all.
FY 21-22.annualBudget: Annual budget projection is approximately $1.5 million. Salary is estimated at about $1.1 million, and equipment and miscellaneous expenses are estimated at $400,000.
FY 21-22.goal1: 1. Operate and maintain all 222 statewide weather stations of the NYS Mesonet during 2020 - 2021 with a combined 97.5%+ uptime.
FY 21-22.goal2: To lead and support grant sponsored research of at least $1 million during the 2020-2021 season.
FY 21-22.goal3: Expand NYS Mesonet communications through increased peer-reviewed publications and media.
FY 21-22.goal4: Expand NYS Mesonet educational outreach to at least 20 institutional partners.
FY 21-22.goal5: Formal, collaborative partnerships with 20+ external organizations that either pay for Mesonet data and/or collaborating with the NYS Mesonet on research activities.
FY 21-22.actions1:
(a) Continued improvement in data quality control software.
(b) Continued training of field staff.
(c) Continued sensor rotation of aging sensors and equipment.
FY 21-22.actions2:
Continued internal collaborations (e.g., ASRC, DAES, COE, School of Public Health, and others) and external partnerships (e.g., Consolidated Edison, Inc., Syracuse University, Cornell University, CUNY, and others).
Expanded education and outreach.
FY 21-22.actions3:
(a) Make peer-reviewed journal writing a specific focus for some research activities. 
(b) Expand web/Facebook/Twitter presence.
(c) Expand media opportunities for the Mesonet.
FY 21-22.actions4: Continued partnership with the UAlbany School of Education; proposal submission, and engagement with the Master Teach program.
FY 21-22.metrics1: All data are archived and daily statistics are compiled to record the percentage of all data received in real-time.  We have a detailed record of all station uptime percentages for all periods.
FY 21-22.metrics2: We will track and monitor the total amount of new and ongoing grant dollars received.
FY 21-22.metrics3:
1. Track the number of journal articles submitted for peer review.
2. Track the number of formal publications referencing Mesonet.
3. Track the number of followers on Facebook/Twitter/web.
4. Track the number and frequency of media stories following Mesonet.
FY 21-22.metrics4: We will monitor and track the number of engaged K-12 partners utilizing NYS Mesonet data and integrating it into school curriculum.
FY 21-22.metrics5: The number of formal collaborative partners will be regularly monitored.
FY 21-22.impactWorkplan1: Significant loss of funding during 2021, which would require a reduction in staff.  This would directly impact the speed at which sensors are repaired and/or replaced.
FY 21-22.impactWorkplan2: Changes in staff and/or changes in financial support to the center.
FY 21-22.impactWorkplan3: A reduction in NYS Mesonet funding and or staff changes.
FY 21-22.impactWorkplan4: Changes to NYS Mesonet staff and/or changes to financial support of the program.
FY 21-22.impactWorkplan5: Changes in NYS Mesonet staff and/or changes in the financial support of the center.
FY 21-22.collaboratingUnits1: ASRC and DAES.  Both organizations provide critical in-kind technical and administrative support.
FY 21-22.collaboratingUnits2: DAES, ASRC, and Sponsored Programs Administration.
FY 21-22.collaboratingUnits4: School of Education, Master Teachers Program.
FY 21-22.impactResearchExcellence1:
Federal funding to the NYS Mesonet via the National Mesonet Program requires a network uptime of at least 95%.  So this metric ensures that this federal flow-through money continues.  
Furthermore, this metric ensures that the NYS Mesonet provides the highest quality and most complete data set to support numerous other research grants on campus.
FY 21-22.impactResearchExcellence2: The Mesonet's focus on building a research portfolio supports the university's goal to "Identify and support innovative research opportunities..."  We have collaborated in over 20 proposals since the Mesonet was started five years ago, and continue to build and strengthen these partnerships.
FY 21-22.impactResearchExcellence3: This goal support innovative research activities by expanding our user base and expanding our collaborative opportunities with both internal and external partners.
FY 21-22.impactResearchExcellence4: Engagement with K-12 schools provides excellent innovative outreach and research opportunities.
FY 21-22.impactResearchExcellence5: Expanded partnerships will increase research and outreach opportunities.

FY 20-21.mission: The mission of the Institute for Health and the Environment is to promote interdisciplinary research and training among faculty from the various schools and colleges of UAlbany. While this is certainly true for local and regional activities, a major focus of the Institute is to promote international research and training activities.
FY 20-21.vision: The vision of the Institute is to increase collaborative research and training among the faculty from the various schools and colleagues of the University at Albany as well as to promote closer ties to collaborators at other institutions, especially international institutions.
FY 20-21.annualBudget: Finances are a major problem for the Institute.  We have only one state line, and both of the Co-Directors are for budgets purposes within the School of Public Health.  The School of Public Health is increasingly unwilling to share indirect costs with the Institute, and the one faculty member assigned to the Institute has not been successful in obtaining grants.  Furthermore the University has decided to no longer allow me as Director to put funds obtained in expert witness work into an RF account, which has up to now been a major source of support.

FY 20-21.topAchievements1: At the invitation of the World Health Organization we have prepared and submitted to WHO a draft of a manuscript on E-waste in Africa.  Two of our UAlbany African PhD students are the first two authors, with co-authorship from professionals in Ghana, NIH, Australia and staff from WHO.  The manuscript will soon be submitted to a peer-reviewed scientific journal.
FY 20-21.topAchievements2: The Institute is hosting a Brazilian pre-doctoral Fulbright Fellow.
FY 20-21.topAchievements3: The Institute staff are advisors to eight doctoral students (PhD or DrPH) at present.  These students come from Serra Leone, Nigeria, Iran, Mongolia, Trinidad, Japan, Bangladesh and the US.
FY 20-21.topAchievements4: Of 11 peer-reviewed publications coming from the Institute this year, five were the work of doctoral students.
FY 20-21.topAchievements5: Drs. Carpenter and Feingold participated in a WHO-sponsored conference held in Montevideo, Uruguay.
FY 20-21.goal1: To promote interdisciplinary research and training.
FY 20-21.goal2: Promote international activities and training.
FY 20-21.goal3: Increase and contribute to community-based activities.
FY 20-21.actions1: This has been a challenging year because of COVID.  However we have made progress in both research and training, as reflected in numbers of publications and students.
FY 20-21.actions2: Prof. Feingold has obtained a major Fogarty International fellowship but collaborative work in Peru.
FY 20-21.actions3: To have Institute members be active in community organizations.
FY 20-21.metrics1: Numbers of publications, grants obtained and student trained.
FY 20-21.metrics2: Grants, publications and students trained.
FY 20-21.metrics3: Dr. Carpenter serves as a member of several community groups, including the Advisory Committee to the Mayor of Albany for the South End.  He is the treasurer of the Healthy Schools Network, a national advocacy organization.  He is the Chair of the Board of the International Institute for Health and Education, a California-based organization with activities in the Middle East, he is a board member of RADIX Ecological Sustainability Center, an Albany-based adovcacy organization in the South End.  He has also been active in community groups focused on the Dunn Demolition Landfill in Rensselaer, concerns about air pollution in Warren County, New York and work with the Alaska Community Action on Toxics in fighting the development of the Donlin Gold Mine.

FY 20-21.timeframe3: These are continuing problems that will not go away any time soon.
FY 20-21.actionsImplemented2: We have all worked to accomplish these goals.

FY 20-21.noteworthyResults2: we have been successful in meeting our goals.
FY 20-21.noteworthyResults3: None of these issues are resolved, but we have gotten good press on many of the issues, including TV interviews, articles in the Albany Times Union.

FY 20-21.changes2: Our goals were met in spite of COVID
FY 20-21.changes3: These are problems that are not easily solved and these activities will continue in the next year.

FY 20-21.bigChallenges: Obtaining funding and recruiting the really good students.
FY 20-21.strategicSuggestions: Write more good grant applications and expand support for students without which one cannot be competitive.

FY 21-22.mission: To promote interdisciplinary research and training among faculty from the various schools and colleges of the University at Albany, other local academic and governmental institutions and international partners.

FY 20-21.mission:
The mission of the Center for Functional Genomics is to develop expertise on new and
developing genomic technologies that advance and improve the understanding of
biology. As part of its mission, the CFG maintains core competencies in genomics,
epitranscriptomics, epigenetics and bioinformatics.
FY 20-21.vision:
The Center for Functional Genomics provides state-of-the-art services that enables
scientists to conduct innovative research utilizing resources for which cost, operational
investment, and expertise is most efficiently and effectively supported as a shared
resource, fostering the growth of biotechnology at the University at Albany and
throughout the Capital Region.
FY 20-21.annualBudget:
CFG operating costs are offset by current year income - both state and RF
Although there are 5 RF employees, 2 are FTE, and 3 are 50% 
Obviously income will post as it comes in so numbers will be higher on June 30,2021

FY 20-21.otherActivities:
Elected to Executive Board of the Association for Biomolecular Resource Facilities
Selected as a judge for the 2020 COVID X-Prize
FY 20-21.topAchievements1: Was part of an international effort to develop a LAMP based assay for Covid-19. This resulted in 3 publications: One paper that has been accepted, two that are in review of which one is a major review article from the gLAMP consortium that will serve as a viable resource for the field
FY 20-21.topAchievements2: Successfully developed a method for waste water surveillance of sars-cov2 in a collaboration with Dept. of Environmental & sustainable Engineering and UA Facilities.
FY 20-21.topAchievements3: Being elected to the ABRF Executive Board and as a Judge for the 2020 International Covid X-Prize highlighted the expertise of Dr. Chittur and his laboratory at UAlbany to groups worldwide.
FY 20-21.topAchievements4: Successfully applied to the SUNY SEED grant for developing a Covid test. We also were a partner with the RNA Institute in their successful application with SUNY Upstate.
FY 20-21.topAchievements5: Maintained our laboratory services through the pandemic and thus were able to enable multiple investigators to achieve their targets.
FY 20-21.goal1: Development of new genomic methods for transcriptomics and epitranscriptomics to enable investigators at UAlbany and collaborating institutions to advance research.
FY 20-21.goal2: Continue to be a viable resource for the University especially in its pandemic efforts
FY 20-21.goal3: Keep our aging instrumentation viable
FY 20-21.actions1: Build workflow pipelines for new methodologies to enable Chip-seq, ATAC-Seq, Cut-n-RunSeq and single cell applications
FY 20-21.actions2:
Keep laboratory open and running to accept samples from investigators
Develop methods for Covid testing from saliva
Develop methods for wastewater surveillance

FY 20-21.actionsImplemented1:

Built analysis pipelines to check quality of workflows
FY 20-21.actionsImplemented2:
Implemented new safety measures in the lab to promote safety of personnel
Literature review and webinars attended to gain knowledge on current methods
Participated as a member of the gLAMP consortium
FY 20-21.actionsImplemented3:
Regular maintenance of equipment
Develop new assays using LAMP for qPCR instrument
FY 20-21.noteworthyResults1:
Paper in submission
Successful in developing workflow pipelines for Chip-Seq, ATAC-Seq and Cut-n-Run Seq experiments. 
Also successful in developing workflows for single cell sequencing for gene expression, immune profiling and antigen specificity
FY 20-21.noteworthyResults2:
We were able to keep operations open without any infections
Completed 64 different projects that generated revenue and provided data to investigators
Developed a LAMP based rapid test to detect sars-cov2 from saliva in 30 min @ less than $3/rxn
Developed a method to detect sars-cov2 from wastewater samples
3 publications on COVID testing
FY 20-21.noteworthyResults3:
We have manged to keep our Agilent Bioanalyzer running for 16 yrs without a service contract
Dual LAMP assay for sars-cov2 developed on our qPCR instrument
New assays for wastewater surveillance developed on qPCR instrument
FY 20-21.changes3:
We no longer have service contracts on some of our instruments. This is especially risky since instrumentation repairs can be expensive. We did manage to upgrade parts on these instruments before contracts ran out.
The Nextseq500 sequencer is reaching its end of use and the newer instruments such as the Nextseq2000 can provide same or better data for the same price point. Currently we are in discussion with the RNA Institute and the LSRB to see how we could partner with them to upgrade this critical instrumentation
FY 20-21.otherThoughtsToGrowResearch:
Partnering with the LSRB/RNA Institute: The RNA Institute recently acquired a 10x genomics instrument for single cell sequencing. The LSRB also has an imaging core. There is a strong possibility of funds available for purchase of a Nextseq 2000 sequencer. If the CFG could be moved to the LSRB, co-location can enable us to venture in to new areas such as Spatial transcriptomics which combines single cell, imaging and NGS as is gaining fast popularity. Investigators can also think about multi-omic approaches to science.
Partnering with ETEC: Joint partnership with the Dept. Environmental & Sustainable Engineering will enable us to target funding opportunities for Metagenomics.
FY 20-21.bigChallenges:
1. Our instrumentation is aging and needs upgrading/replacement
2. Our current operational models are in need of revision: (a) CFG needs to be added to grant funding proposals we support more regularly. (b) Currently it takes a lot of time and effort to track payments between RF, State to reconcile with our own records that are more up to date. (c)Deficit funding does not allow us to forecast our future budgets effectively.
3. There is no marketing or advisory support for our services. While we have been doing a decent job, it would help to reconstitute a Scientific Advisory Board and a Faculty Advisory Board for guidance and direction
FY 20-21.resourceNeeds:
1. Nextseq 2000 sequencer
2. Scientific Advisory Board and a Faculty Advisory Board for guidance and direction
3. Inclusion with other units to better focus on University priorities
FY 20-21.strategicSuggestions:
1. Relocate to main campus to be better integrated with Life Science Initiatives
2. Look for synergies between various core facilities on campus to develop new methods. Currently each facility runs independently without strategic overlaps in vision/priorities.
FY 20-21.otherthoughts: Inclusion in meeting or marketing our services when Life Science focused startups are considering locating to the Health Science Incubator campus or possibly ETEC.

FY 20-21.mission: The RNA Epitranscriptomics and Proteomics Resources (REPR) was created by consolidating the RNA analysis and proteomics capabilities existing at the University at Albany. This specialized resource offers an extensive range of state-of-the-art mass spectrometry instrumentation and know-how. The mission is to capitalize on the extensive expertise in the analysis of RNA, RNA modifications, and proteins involved in RNA metabolism/regulation to benefit both internal and external investigators interested in these types of topics.
FY 20-21.vision: The resource supports also projects involving the analysis of a wide range of biomolecules, metabolites, and small synthetic molecules. In addition to providing full-service analysis, REPR welcomes the opportunity to enter full-fledged partnerships that may involve extensive consulting on experimental design, sample preparation and data interpretation, as well as whole project development and grant writing contributions. Please, contact us to inquire on how we can best help you.
FY 20-21.annualBudget:
REPR uses current year's income to offset our expenditures.  We collect both State and RF money.  Income (as of 5/18/2021) is listed in "additional funding sources"
Income #'s will change  as it will increase as it is posted until 6/30/2021.

FY 19-20.mission: The Atmospheric Sciences Research Center (ASRC), of the State University of New York at Albany, was established on February 16, 1961 by the Board of Trustees of the State University of New York, as a SUNY system-wide resource for developing and administering programs in basic and applied sciences related to the atmospheric environment. ASRC's world-class researchers study the physical and chemical processes of the atmosphere, land, and water systems, and apply that knowledge to explore the interaction of chemical, physical, geological and biological processes that impact our environment. Through technology transfer and collaboration with state, federal and industrial partners, ASRC enhances New York State's scientific capacity and infrastructure, while advancing the quality of life and economic wellbeing of its citizens.
FY 19-20.annualBudget: ASRC's annual operating budget is derived from IFR from sponsored funds. Most of our payroll is provided by state funding. Any gaps in payroll are covered by our IFR accounts.

FY 19-20.topAchievements1:
Dr. Sara Lance received an NSF Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) award from NSF ($684K) to study the chemistry taking place in clouds around Whiteface Mountain. In addition to supporting basic science it will also support a chemistry/climate summer camp serving students from local school districts in the Albany area. See: https://www.albany.edu/news/93279.php

This directly contributes to the second priority included in the 2019/20 Action Plan for ASRC that was concerned with elevating the facility and science taking place at the Whiteface Mountain Field Station.
FY 19-20.topAchievements2:
In collaboration with Dr.'s Richard Perez and Jeff Freedman a whitepaper was created that provides a vision for how weather information, including the NYS Mesonet, will help NY State achieve its 100% renewables goal by 2040. Efforts are ongoing to promote this with the State and the public. Interviews were also given on “Capitol Tonight” on Spectrum News and for the “Capital Pressroom”, WCNY. ASRC leads a number of funded research projects that deal with renewable energy. 

A major multi-partner DOE grant for around $10M was led and submitted by Dr Jeff Freedman, concerned with a field experiment focused on off-shore wind. 

This directly contributes to the third priority included in the 2019/20 Action Plan for ASRC concerned with elevating and promoting ASRC expertise in renewable energy.
FY 19-20.goal1: Establish and Promote Weather-AI and Data Analytics capabilities at ASRC building on the newly established xCITE laboratory– Specifically: (1) Promote usage of the xCITE laboratory in ASRC, DAES and the University campus in the area of Artificial intelligence and Machine Learning. Measurable: number of users. (2) Initiate a campus Weather AI/ML group to exchange ideas, promote research and coordinate research proposals. Measurable: number of members in the group (3) Secure additional external funding in the Weather-AI and Data analytics domain. Measurable: booked research support (4) Increase exposure of the xCITE facility and related activities through publications, conference/workshop demonstrations; website; logos, media and marketing etc: Measurable: Numbers of papers, presentations, public awareness.
FY 19-20.goal2: Expand and Promote Atmospheric Chemistry and Air Quality Research and Outreach activities at ASRC’s facility at White Face Mountain (WFM): (1) Maintain and extend external research funding for field research at WFM that expands upon and complements the long term measurements obtained at the site which began nearly 50 years ago. Measurable: booked research support (2) Elevate the profile of research conducted at WFM by publishing findings from projects in peer reviewed journals, presenting findings at national and international conferences, and participating in outreach activities including celebration of 50th Anniversary in 2020. Measurable: Numbers of papers, presentations and public awareness (3) Maintain and develop research infrastructure at WFM to enhance research capabilities and collaboration at the site. Measurable: Infrastructure fidelity and usefulness, number of collaborations. (4) A related goal is to start the EIP air quality scientist hiring process (in collaboration with Stony Brook) – subject to University permission. Measurable: a successful search
FY 19-20.goal3: Expand and Promote Renewable Energy Research at ASRC – Specifically: (1) Start the EIP renewable energy scientist hiring process - subject to University permission. Measurable: a successful search (2) Secure additional external funding to support this work (e.g. NOAA, NSF, NYSERDA. Measurable: booked research support (3) Build R&D relationships on the perfect forecast/firm power generation concepts via COE, EdESLR. Measurable: project prospects. (4) Expand ASRC’s renewable energy group’s R&D and collaborative partnerships in offshore wind. Measurable: funding/collaboration through public/private partnerships, COE engagement (5) Promote ASRC’s research portfolio in renewables through publications, presentations and outreach to public and State Government. Measurable: Numbers of publications and presentations, media and NY State awareness,
FY 19-20.goal4: Expand ASRC’s portfolio in hydrology research including exploitation of NYS Mesonet observations, Specifically: (1) To promote and establish research that contributes to improving NOAA’s National Water Model through data assimilation efforts that includes mesonet and satellite data; integrating the NWM products into U.S. Drought Monitor and improving representation of groundwater-streamflow interactions. Measured by: improvements to the NYM and improved objectivity of the U.S Drought Monitor, (2) Enhance relationships and collaborations with hydrological groups in NY State including Canal Corporation (NYPA), USGS and NOAA’s NE River Forecasting Center. Measured by: increased interactions and projects with these entities. (3) Secure funding for all or part of the research described in the NSF STC Pre-proposal “SAFER” that deals with user-driven adaptive modeling of flood risk. Measurable: booked research support.
FY 19-20.goal5: Establish an Undergraduate Recruitment Plan taking advantage of Weather-Climate Enterprise Assets, Specifically: (1) Working with NYS Mesonet, COE and DAES, establish and implement a recruitment plan that takes advantage of the presence of NYS Mesonet stations across the State. Measurable: number of students applying to STEM fields at UAlbany as a result of this activity. (2) Include in this strategy a Media and Marketing effort to promote the Weather and Climate Enterprise across the State. Measurable: Public awareness.
FY 19-20.actions1:
(i) Kara Sulia and Chris Thorncroft will have monthly meetings to ensure the goals are met. This will include discussions about research activity, related metrics and outreach activity building on the AI Institute efforts.
(ii) A Weather AI/ML scientific group will be formed as outlined above.
FY 19-20.actions2:
(i) In addition to PI-led group meetings, wider quarterly group meetings with Jim Schwab, Sara Lance and other key faculty and staff will help us to be successful with our overarching goal and sub-goals.
(ii) The search committee will be aggressive in advertising the position in the community.
FY 19-20.actions3:
(i) In addition to regular group meetings, regular strategic discussions between the Director and Richard Perez and other key faculty will take place to ensure we are successful; bringing in other key personnel as needed.
(ii) Engage further with NY State on importance of ASRC research in this domain; including more promotion of Whitepaper created in 2019 (updated if needed).
(iii) Permission to start search for EIP position; then the search committee will aggressively recruit.
FY 19-20.actions4:
(i) In addition to regular group meetings, regular strategic discussions between the Director and Fangqun Yu and other key faculty will take place to ensure we are successful; bringing in other key personnel as needed.
(ii) To establish regular interactions between ASRC and NCAR scientists to establish scientific collaborations in this area of research.
FY 19-20.actions5:
(i) In addition to regular group meetings, regular strategic discussions between the Director, Scott Miller, Sarah Lu and other key faculty will take place to ensure we are successful; bringing in other key personnel as needed.
(ii) To ensure regular meetings with key strategic partners including CUNY, Stonybrook and University of Oklahoma

FY 19-20.noteworthyResults2:
New funding included Sara Lance’s NSF Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) award from NSF ($684K) to study the chemistry taking place in clouds around Whiteface Mountain. Also Jim Schwab’s NYSERDA award ($399K) to support “Mobile Laboratory Measurements of Methane, Ethane, and Co-pollutants from Landfills, Oil and Gas Systems and Other Sources in New York State” is recommended for funding. Also, Jim Schwab received a new Sub-award from the University of Rochester to study “Long-Term Monitoring of Methane within NYS Phase II: Assessing Trends in Sources and Characterizing Hot Spots”, ($22,044)(M1)

(i)Established plans to celebrate the 50th Anniversary of Whiteface including contributions to the Falconer public seminar series in summer, a white paper on the vision for the next decades, a banquet (to be held in Albany; will invite DEC Commissioner to speak) and an invitation to host a visit to Whiteface for President Rodriguez and members of his executive council. (M2)

(ii)The following papers were published (M2):

(iii)The ASRC Whiteface Mountain Field Station has been working to improve the infrastructure at the summit observatory over the past year. We started out 2020 with plans for upgrades to the observatory including structural repairs as well as electrical upgrades and a roof replacement project. These plans were to coincide with the 50th anniversary of the observatory and also to predicate deployment of several new instruments by Dr. Sara Lance. Several meetings were held with Facilities Management staff as well as the design team from CSARCH. The work was put out to bid in April 2020. Only one bid was received and was determined to be too high. Due to financial constraints related to the COVID-19 pandemic it was decided that the scope of the project should be reduced and put back out to bid. We decided to focus on the most urgent need which is the roof replacement. However even with the reduced scope of work we were informed that there were not funds available to move forward this year. The current plan is to have staff from the UALBANY roofing shop come up on Wednesday 9/16/2020 to attempt to refasten the existing roof to get us through the winter. We are hopeful that a more permanent fix will be forthcoming in the near future. (M3)

(iv)The EIP search was initiated. (M4)
FY 19-20.noteworthyResults3:
(i)New funding included Richard Perez’s continued support from Clean Power Research ($300K) and Natural Resource Canada ($75K). (M2)

(ii)Richard Perez published extensively on the perfect forecast/firm power – 3 joint peer-review articles, 2 invited conference presentations and several webinars (M3)

(iii)The Firm Power forecast is one of the research foci for the Clean Power Research Project (see above). (M3)

(iv)Richard spearheaded and is now leading a new International Energy Agency Task on Firm Power Generation: IEA PVPS Task 16 3.5. (M3)

(v)Jeff Freedman led a DOE Offshore Wind proposal: leading a team with 5 universities, 4 private sector partners on a $14.5 million (with cost-share) proposal to conduct an observational and modeling campaign on the offshore wind resource along the mid-Atlantic and northeast coastal waters. (M4)

(vi)Jeff Freedman, Co-chaired the AMS 11th Conference on Weather, Climate, and the New Energy Economy (January 2020) and was Invited to lead a panel on climate and extreme weather at the American Wind Energy Association Wind Resource Assessment conference (end of September 2020).

(vii)Dr.'s Richard Perez and Jeff Freedman (together with Jerry Brotzge and Chris Thorncroft)  created a whitepaper that provides a vision for how weather information, including the NYS Mesonet, will help NY State achieve its 100% renewables goal by 2040. Efforts are ongoing to promote this with the State and the public. Interviews were also given on “Capitol Tonight” on Spectrum News and for the “Capital Pressroom”, WCNY. (M5)

(viii)	Publications include (M5):

Perez R. et al., (2020) From Firm Solar Power Forecasts to Firm Solar Power Generation an Effective Path to Ultra-High renewable Penetration a New York Case Study. Energies 2020, 13, 4489.

Pierro M., R. Perez, M. Perez, D. Moser, M. Giacomo and C. Cornaro, (2020) Italian protocol for massive solar integration: imbalance mitigation strategies. Renewable Energy journal, 153, pp 725-739

Pierro, M., Moser, D., Perez, R., Cornaro, C. The Value of PV Power Forecast and the Paradox of the “Single Pricing” Scheme: The Italian case Study, Energies 2020, 12, 3045
FY 19-20.noteworthyResults4:
(i)Performed visual quality screening of New York State Mesonet (NYSM) soil moisture observational records at 119 stations. Identified data quality issues related to frozen soil conditions, service disruptions, as well as site- and soil moisture retrieval-specific soil type disparities. These issues were reported to the NYSM, which addressed the frozen soil and disruption effects in a March 2020 reprocessed release of the full NYSM soil moisture and temperature record (November 2015–December 2019). Soil type corrections will be left to the discretion of the end-user. (M1)

(ii)Demonstrated added-value of NASA Soil Moisture Active Passive satellite-derived soil moisture data assimilation in a short-term weather forecast context in conditionally-accepted article in Monthly Weather Review (M1): 

Ferguson, C.R., S. Agrawal, M. Beauharnois, G. Xia, D.A. Burrows and L. Bosart (2020), Satellite soil moisture assimilation for improved forecasts of Great Plains low-level jet ramp events, Mon. Wea. Rev..

(iii)Development of a mesonet--National Water Model-satellite soil moisture data fusion approach is ongoing in collaboration with Princeton University and Duke University collaborators. Once proven, the approach will be integrated in the form of an observational operator in the U.S. multi-agency Joint Effort for Data Assimilation Integration (JEDI) system.  (M1)

(iv)A proposal was submitted to NASA to develop dynamic vegetation root-groundwater interactions within the National Water Model.  (M1)

(v)A proposal to NASA to extend the SMAP soil moisture data assimilation work was not selected for funding but will be resubmitted in some form. (M1)

(vi)Efforts remain ongoing to develop collaborations with the Canal Corporation, USGS and the NE River Forecasting Center. USGS is currently incorporating one NYS Mesonet station into its ice-jamming monitoring efforts. (M2)

(vii)	A proposal is currently planned for submission in the coming year that is based on SAFER. Partners currently include ASRC, DAES, CEHC and Penn State. (M3)
FY 19-20.noteworthyResults5:
(i)June Wang (NYS Mesonet) has developed relationships with key people in SOE and in some local schools and has led a proposal on “Backyard Weather Science: A Data Intensive online Environment for next generation STEM teaching and learning”. (M1)

(ii)Media and marketing are working on a story that highlights a summer interaction between the NYS Mesonet (June Wang) and a local school teacher. (M2)
FY 19-20.changes1: There has been a delay in establishing the campus-wide weather AI/ML group due to bandwidth, but we will endeavor to achieve this in the coming year, buoyed by the new AI institute.
FY 19-20.changes2: Due to the pandemic, the WFM Field Station 50th Anniversary celebrations were postponed and will now hopefully take place in late summer 2021.
FY 19-20.changes3: The EIP hire was delayed due to University budget issues
FY 19-20.changes4: The proposal based on SAFER was delayed due to bandwidth. Efforts are ongoing to create a new proposal in the next 6 months.
FY 19-20.changes5: This effort requires funding and so more efforts will be made to achieve this.  Consideration will be given to establishing a committee led by June Wang.
FY 19-20.otherThoughtsToGrowResearch:
There are several big opportunities for significant growth at ASRC:
 
(i)Weather-AI – Need to initiate the Winter Weather project in the AI Institute and leverage this for more research activity beyond that which is funded by NSF.

(ii)Renewable Energy – This remains a topic that we need to maintain strength in and grow.

(iii)Planetary Boundary Layer and Air Quality  - There is a big opportunity to grow this area and to establish collaborations with Oklahoma University and CUNY.
FY 19-20.resourceNeeds:
(i) Resources to hire the two EIP positions (replacing retired faculty)
(ii) Resources to maintain COE
(iii) Resources to run the NYS Mesonet
FY 19-20.strategicSuggestions:
(i) Working with Federal lobbyist towards establishing Federal support for Boundary layer/Profiler research through appropriations.

(ii) Working with Federal lobbyist and Oklahoma University to establish partnership with respect to their NOAA CI re-bid in 2021.

(iii) Continue to collaborate with CEHC together with DAES on research and research proposals.

(iv) Continue to strengthen research ties with Wadsworth and School of Public Health.
FY 19-20.otherthoughts: If we want to take advantage of the huge opportunities that exist in Atmospheric Sciences research we should endeavor to fill the two EIP positions.

FY 19-20.mission: To advance scientific knowledge of the physics, chemistry, and engineering of materials through the use of Ion Beams.
FY 19-20.vision: To contribute to a deeper understanding of scientific phenomena by providing a valuable experimental tool and resource of researchers at UAlbany, other educational, industry, and Federal agencies.
FY 19-20.annualBudget: The Extrion implanter was down for repairs most of the year, this affected the revenues generated. These revenues are included "additional Resources below.

FY 19-20.propertyDisclosures: Proof of concept for at least one IP application (likely filed) by Rabi Musah on therapy that employs neutron beam was obtained using the Ion Beam Lab. Details were not provided to IBL.
FY 19-20.keynoteAddresses: IBL is a service organization. Its employees and staff do not normally make presentations at conferences.
FY 19-20.topAchievements1: Completed Phase 1 of the Extrion implanter redesign and rebuilding. We have gathered most of the materials needed for phase two (Covid has complicated this). Written 90% of the control software needed for phase two.
FY 19-20.topAchievements2:
We were able to add capabilities to the facility that expanded the value of our facility to our users. 

(See details in the Goals and results section)
FY 19-20.goal1: To expand the usage of the IBL by designing and implementing methods of  specialized characterization work that can be performed by IBL staff for outside entities. This will expand both our research utility as well as our revenue opportunities.
FY 19-20.goal2: To redesign and rebuild the Extrion Implant Accelerator. This refit will increase its capabilities, allowing us to expand our research utility, and simplify its use for operators which will increase its use.
FY 19-20.goal3: Expand the capabilities of the Facility to increase its utility to a more diverse customer base.
FY 19-20.goal4: The IBL is currently working to replace support systems that have exceeded their service life in an effort to lower the overall energy consumption of the facility. It is also working on installing new control systems on the Dynamitron and the Extrion to better manage the system itself and also better manage their energy consumption. These efforts fall in line with SUNY’s overall efforts to lower the its energy consumption. As a facility dedicated to the study of the natural world it is imperative that the IBL participates in its conservation.
FY 19-20.goal5: Increase educational support at the IBL.
FY 19-20.actionsImplemented1:
The IBL has performed analysis work for industry partners like IBM, BMW, Intel, Nokomis and Radiation Dynamics. This work is in addition to the ever expanding list of outside universities that we have performed sample analysis for. 

These activities help concentrate research and development efforts in new and exciting fields here in the Capital District.
FY 19-20.actionsImplemented2:
The IBL has completed the first phase of the project which was to design and have manufactured a new high voltage power supply. The design work was done in-house and the construction was done off site.  

The path forward has been outlined and materials are being purchased in preparation for phase two.
FY 19-20.actionsImplemented3:
Reconfigure the 30 degree line to produce both high and low energy neutrons.

Designed and built a new end station on the 20 degree line to attach a cryo containment vessel to expose samples provided by outside users to simulated solar wind.

These efforts have added to the overall capabilities of the IBL facility.
FY 19-20.actionsImplemented4: Some efforts have been made on this front but Staffing constraints have slowed progress.
FY 19-20.actionsImplemented5: The IBL continues to support education by providing access to the facilities in order to educate/train both graduate and undergraduate students. These efforts include graduate student training and undergraduate lab experiments to support lab classes like PHY 335.
FY 19-20.noteworthyResults1: We were able to increase revenue through the sale of characterization services to outside entities in spite of the downtime of the Extrion.
FY 19-20.noteworthyResults2:
The power supply has been incorporated into the system and functions as designed.

The phase two materials are almost all in-house (Covid has slowed this to a crawl) and the control software has been mostly written.
FY 19-20.noteworthyResults3:
We were able to produce thermal neutrons to facilitate testing of a compound developed by Prof Rabi Musah in the SUNY Albany Chemistry department. This research will be used to develop better methods of treating cancer using Boron Neutron Capture Therapy.

We were also able to produce high energy neutrons to create reference samples for  Prof Cecilia Levy in the SUNY Albany Physics department, This research was being conducted jointly with RPI and is part of an ongoing research project to detect Dark mater particles using geological samples. 

We were able to utilize the 20 degree line to expose samples for the US Air Force that were being analyzed by George Nelson at RIT in collaboration with Radiation Dynamics Inc.. This research will help develop the models used by the Air Force and NASA to calculate solar wind damage experienced by satellites in earth orbit.
FY 19-20.noteworthyResults5: We now have an additional 5 grad students qualified to work at the IBL belonging to three different universities.
FY 19-20.changes2: This effort has been hampered by the current staffing deficiencies that we are working with.
FY 19-20.changes3: This effort has been hampered by the current staffing deficiencies that we are working with.
FY 19-20.changes4: This effort has been hampered by the current staffing deficiencies that we are working with.
FY 19-20.otherThoughtsToGrowResearch: The IBL has the opportunity to participate in the fields of space weather, geology, biology and material science. This would increase our research utility as well as increase our revenues.
FY 19-20.bigChallenges:
The (IBL) is composed of several experimental systems that have a wide range of sizes and complexity. Each of these systems is comprised of a collection of both mechanical and electronic components, each with its own maintenance needs and operational service life. 

In order for any manufacturing or experimental system to function efficiently and extend the operational service life, each component within that system requires a well thought out, and carefully adhered to maintenance schedule. However, not adhering to the maintenance regime can, and often does lead to the premature failure of components resulting in the need for expensive repair or replacement. Unexpected component failures lead to unscheduled down time leading to the expenditure of time and capital that could otherwise be utilized to extend the capabilities of the system. 

The IBL has traditionally functioned with a contingent of personnel that ensured that the systems comprising the IBL had the care and scrutiny described above. The team consisted two to three technicians and engineers to maintain the systems and implement any upgrades or refits.  This staffing level was maintained for the forty plus years that the IBL had been in existence. 

The current contingent consists of one technician and a part-time project manager. This staffing level is no longer sufficient to meet the needs of the IBL and its continued operation, let alone expand and grow. As a result of the staffing shortfall, routine maintenance has been deferred resulting in unscheduled down time and avoidable expense. As a consequence, the time devoted to the unscheduled repairs further diminishes the time available for routine maintenance which leads to addition unscheduled downs. This spiraling degradation of the IBL’s capabilities over a decade of neglect has reached a near unsustainable level and needs to be addressed before the trend becomes unrecoverable. It goes without saying that if the day to day maintenance of the IBL systems are suffering, then the development and implementation of a Strategic Plan is impossible.
 
The current situation has already adversely affected research being performed at UAlbany as well as other Academic and Industrial affiliates. To continue on this path would eventually lead to a situation where the IBL would not be able to fulfill its Mission.
FY 19-20.resourceNeeds: The IBL requires at least one more additional full time Technician to help maintain the systems at the IBL. It would also benefit from a capital investment by the university to upgrade and modernize some of the aging components that are prone to failure. This would also lower our energy consumption which would be inline with the universities overall energy goals.
FY 19-20.strategicSuggestions: Have a modernized and efficient, fully staffed facility.
FY 19-20.otherthoughts: The IBL is a unique facility that has capabilities that are not available anywhere else in the world. Although it lies under ground and mostly unknown by the wider University population, its past impact on the development of our modern understanding of material science is profound. Moving forward, its expanded capabilities and practices should allow it to continue to contribute to our collective understanding of the universe in a very meaningful way. This of course is dependent on whether or not the IBL has the resources needed to first maintain, and then advance its capabilities.

FY 19-20.mission: The mission of the Center for Functional Genomics is to develop expertise on new and developing genomic technologies that advance and improve the understanding of biology. As part of its mission, the CFG maintains core competencies in genomics, epitranscriptomics, epigenetics and bioinformatics.
FY 19-20.vision: The Center for Functional Genomics provides state-of-the-art services that enables scientists to conduct innovative research utilizing resources for which cost, operational investment, and expertise is most efficiently and effectively supported as a shared resource, fostering the growth of biotechnology at the University at Albany and throughout the Capital Region.
FY 19-20.annualBudget: We had a 37% increase in our revenues (including collections) even with a decrease in our FTEs. Currently we have 2.5 FTEs as laboratory staff and 1.5 FTEs as admin support

FY 19-20.otherActivities:
The Center has participated in soliciting extramural funding either as collaborator or key personnel in 19 grant applications by university faculty.
The core is still part of the R21 grant award with Dr. Larsen (Biology): Endothelial Cell Signaling in Regeneration (01-FEB-18 / 31-JAN-21)
FY 19-20.topAchievements1: Successfully expanded RNA sequencing methods portfolio with methods in analyzing new RNA modifications
FY 19-20.topAchievements2: Development of methods for SARS-Cov2 detection: The lab has been part of a global effort to develop a cheaper assay using isothermal amplification (LAMP) and saliva samples. We were recipients of seed funding from SUNY that resulted in an R21 application.
FY 19-20.goal1: Development of new genomic methods for transcriptomics and epitranscriptomics to enable investigators at UAlbany and collaborating institutions to advance research
FY 19-20.goal2: Workforce development via training students/postdoctoral staff
FY 19-20.actions1: NGS method development for ac4C modification
FY 19-20.actions2:
COVID testing (waste water surveillance)
Development of alternatives for saliva testing (LAMP assay)
FY 19-20.actions3: regular maintenance redeveloping protocols to maximize usage lifetimes
FY 19-20.metrics1: Data generated from Next gen sequencing of modified RNA samples
FY 19-20.metrics2:
number of tests provided
NGS studies on samples collected by RNA Institute through their collaboration with Upstate Medical
FY 19-20.actionsImplemented1: Methods developed for RNA sequencing, single cell sequencing, m6A and m5C modified RNA sequencing
FY 19-20.actionsImplemented2:
Integral part of delivering the Bioinstrumentation program (BMS311, BMS411)
Mentor site for HVCC Biotechnology certificate program
FY 19-20.actionsImplemented3:
-continued to increase intra- and extra mural collaborations with investigators in the capital District
-redeveloping website
FY 19-20.actionsImplemented4:
regular maintenance
redeveloping protocols to maximize usage lifetimes
FY 19-20.noteworthyResults1: Last year we conducted over 44 sequencing experiments with over 500 samples and this work has resulted in 13 publications. Multiple PIs in Biology have successfully secured extramural grant funding based on data generated in our core
FY 19-20.noteworthyResults2: We successfully graduated 4 UG students through the Bioinstrumentation program. We also trained 1 UG student (HVCC), 3 UA graduate students and 1 postdoc in the lab
FY 19-20.noteworthyResults3:
increased # publications
increased grant submissions
in spite of our aging instrumentation, we  were still able to run 465 microarrays for investigators
FY 19-20.noteworthyResults4: We still have the Sanger sequencer (circa 2005) and Affymetrix GeneChip systems (Circa 2003) working and providing services to multiple investigators. We have developed other methods like Cell line authentication and Methylation analysis on the Sanger sequencer.
FY 19-20.changes3:
Need to update instrumentation in lab to be able to provide new cutting edge technologies that are gaining popularity
Older instrumentation have errors that result in us having to repeat the assays multiple time increasing out process cost and time.
FY 19-20.otherThoughtsToGrowResearch: The COVID pandemic while catastrophic  is also an opportunity for CFG to target funding for molecular assay development. The methods we currently use can be retooled to get us involved in infectious disease surveillance, metagenomics and areas for developing biomedical science and engineering
FY 19-20.bigChallenges:
The equipment at CFG is aging with some at 15-18 yrs. Our latest instrument is now 5 yrs old and going to be obsolete soon. Newer technologies allow for cost efficiencies and are gaining popularity. If we do not invest in capital equipment, we will loose our resourcefulness to the scientific community.
With the past RIFs that have been necessary to address the ongoing budget crises, it becomes harder to complete projects if a staff member is ill. Having a liquid handling station would help alleviate this and would also prevent current staff from work-related health issues like carpal tunnel
FY 19-20.resourceNeeds:
Instrumentation upgrades to keep up with technology
Robotics to alleviate load on human work force
A more robust biostatistics and bioinformatics program at the university where we can tap in to. The data generated by our experiments is complex and deters faculty from doing them which in turn makes them less competitive in grant funding.
FY 19-20.strategicSuggestions:
More partnerships with other departments like Biology, Engineering
More collaborative ventures with neighboring area Institutions- we are already a regional resource
More partnerships with area biotechnology companies (fee for service, STTRs)
FY 19-20.otherthoughts:
We write a lot of support letters for faculty at the university but never find out if the grant was funded (unless we were listed for effort). It would be helpful to have a system where we could track this.
It would be helpful to have a better system to track invoice payments. Often our records are waiting for payments to show up on RF or State accounts
It would be good to have a small unit at the university that can refurbish/maintaine scientific equipment. The service contracts on our instruments are expensive but needed to validate the reliability of the complex experiments that are in themselves very expensive both in time and costs.

FY 19-20.mission: CTG UAlbany – formerly known as the Center for Technology in Government at the State University of New York (SUNY) at Albany – is a research institute that works with governments worldwide to help transform public service through innovative approaches to, and applications of, technology, management, and policy. Established in 1993, we pursue new ways to use technology to address practical problems of information management and service delivery in government. CTG UAlbany has collaborated with hundreds of domestic and international researchers on understanding and applying emerging technologies. At the same time, CTG UAlbany has worked with scores of local, state, federal, and international government bodies as a trusted advisor and facilitator of management and policy decisions to govern the use of new technologies as tools for public service transformation.
FY 19-20.vision: Work with governments worldwide transforming public services through innovations in technology, policy and management.
FY 19-20.annualBudget: CTG UAlbany’s financial stability over its 26 years in service as an applied research Institute, has been based on its tenured and experienced faculty, researchers, professional administration and finance and project staff. CTG’s subject matter expertise has an ability to continue to build capacity and capability through its projects and research, while generating the necessary project revenues to support CTG’s operational expenses of over $550K annually.  These annually generated revenues allow CTG to support several project support positions, external UAlbany research faculty, graduate students and its programs or work through MOUs, revenue contracts and research agreements with partners both through the Research Foundation such as federal agencies, corporate sponsors, and international governments or through the University at Albany with state agencies, municipal and local governments, state authorities, and not for profits.   CTG’s FY 2019 PSR state allocation of $971,049  supported 12 FTE’s, during this  fiscal year CTG lost 2 PSR funded positons, one position to WFP committee review of Communications Manager denied for rehiring at $51,000 and the second position to the 15 % state reduction of Sr. Project Assistant at $49,993, totaling $100,993 in permanent state PSR funding.  CTG’s professional staff funded by the PSR allocation are engaged in CTG’s development of new programs and innovations, projects and research proposals, day to day operations, business development activities, academic and community engagement, and other related outreach and dissemination activities within the University and globally.   In 2019, CTG UAlbany conducted 8 Research Foundation sponsored projects and 3 state agency, local government, and not for profits projects simultaneously.  CTG UAlbany revenue generates annually, through various sources, to support CTG’s IFR operational expenditures which for FY 2019 totaled $510,581. CTG’s revenue generation through its various projects supports its annual operational budget of OTPS which includes the following expense categories of  facilities costs (e.g. rent, taxes, utilities), phones, computer equipment and software, graduate students, temp service and term positions, supplies, service contracts, business travel, staff development, conferences, and any other non-PSR  expense needed to operate CTG UAlbany. CTG doesn’t receive an annual OTPS allocation from the Division of Research, instead it revenue generates on its own to support CTG’s OTPS budget.  A unique aspect of CTG’s financial/business model relative to most academic departments and other research units; is that CTG not only relies on its traditional research funded projects, but has many state agency projects, under state MOUs and revenue contracts. These state projects are a part of the strategic business development and financial planning that is the necessary support our annual operational budget. Within this template provided, it doesn’t allow a place for CTG UAlbany to report those state MOUs and Revenue contracts pending, as is the case for pending submitted RF proposals. Therefore, the information is provided here in the narrative.  CTG has several MOUs pending with state agencies such as: 1. NYS BOE’s Future elections at $310,000, 2. NYS BOE Election Remediation Risk at $35,000, along with several other opportunities in the business development, additional work on the project with the United Arab Emirates estimated at an additional $40K and new work with the United Nations for a round two which is in the business development stages. Also, we are submitting a preliminary proposal to IMLS related focused on exploring the role of public libraries as intermediaries of innovation in local and regional contexts.

FY 19-20.otherThoughtsToGrowResearch:
We believe that working with local governments in the Capital Region, New York State, and throughout the country as a big opportunity to advance our research. There continues to be a federal, state, and industry focus on the area of smart cities/communities and investment of information and communication technologies (e.g. machine learning, artificial intelligence, data analytics) at the local government to help improve government operations and provide public services. Given our expertise and research interest in the policy, management, and technology dimensions of information and technology use by governments at all levels, CTG UAlbany can continue to make significant contributions in this area for next 1-5 years.   
We continue to see working with state agencies in New York and beyond as another big opportunity to advance our research. As state governments and individual state agencies try to modernize older and legacy information systems and adopt new data management and analysis techniques there is a lot of opportunity to apply CTG UAlbany's existing expertise and conduct new externally funded research in this area.
We are actively pursuing research project partnerships with faculty and professional researchers at CEHC and ASRC. We see a lot of opportunity to collaborate on policy, technology, and management issues in the emergency preparedness, homeland and cyber security, and weather domains and produce competitive and innovative research proposals.
FY 19-20.bigChallenges: Due to professionals staff leaving and difficulty in rehiring due to current budget constraints, CTG UAlbany has seen a significant decrease in non faculty professional researchers who help manage and provide support to our research and other projects. This is impacting the number and size of projects we can conduct simultaneously.
FY 19-20.resourceNeeds: CTG UAlbany is actively seeking space on campus that will allow ups to be closer to our students, fellow faculty researchers, and campus administration. In addition, space on campus will allow CTG to dedicate more of its external reseach funding dollars to support paid undergradute and graduate interns and assistantships
FY 19-20.strategicSuggestions: Continue to invest in support for proposal development and pre and post award support in general. Also, we think that it is very important to expand the staff and expertise of the UAlbany technology development office. Resources and expertise in this area are critical to helping CTG UAlbany and other researchers at UAlbany determine if and how their research findings can be protected and commercialized.

FY 20-21.mission: CTG UAlbany – formerly known as the Center for Technology in Government at the State University of New York (SUNY) at Albany – is a research institute that works with governments worldwide to help transform public service through innovative approaches to, and applications of, technology, management, and policy. Established in 1993, we pursue new ways to use technology to address practical problems of information management and service delivery in government. CTG UAlbany has collaborated with hundreds of domestic and international researchers on understanding and applying emerging technologies. At the same time, CTG UAlbany has worked with scores of local, state, federal, and international government bodies as a trusted advisor and facilitator of management and policy decisions to govern the use of new technologies as tools for public service transformation.
FY 20-21.vision: Work with governments worldwide transforming public services through innovations in technology, policy and management.
FY 20-21.annualBudget: CTG UAlbany’s financial stability over its 26 years in service as an applied research Institute, has been based on its tenured and experienced faculty, researchers, professional administration and finance and project staff. CTG’s subject matter expertise has an ability to continue to build capacity and capability through its projects and research, while generating the necessary project revenues to support CTG’s operational expenses of over $550K annually.  These annually generated revenues allow CTG to support several project support positions, external UAlbany research faculty, graduate students and its programs or work through MOUs, revenue contracts and research agreements with partners both through the Research Foundation such as federal agencies, corporate sponsors, and international governments or through the University at Albany with state agencies, municipal and local governments, state authorities, and not for profits.   CTG’s FY 2019 PSR state allocation of $971,049  supported 12 FTE’s, during this  fiscal year CTG lost 2 PSR funded positons, one position to WFP committee review of Communications Manager denied for rehiring at $51,000 and the second position to the 15 % state reduction of Sr. Project Assistant at $49,993, totaling $100,993 in permanent state PSR funding.  CTG’s professional staff funded by the PSR allocation are engaged in CTG’s development of new programs and innovations, projects and research proposals, day to day operations, business development activities, academic and community engagement, and other related outreach and dissemination activities within the University and globally.   In 2019, CTG UAlbany conducted 8 Research Foundation sponsored projects and 3 state agency, local government, and not for profits projects simultaneously.  CTG UAlbany revenue generates annually, through various sources, to support CTG’s IFR operational expenditures which for FY 2019 totaled $510,581. CTG’s revenue generation through its various projects supports its annual operational budget of OTPS which includes the following expense categories of  facilities costs (e.g. rent, taxes, utilities), phones, computer equipment and software, graduate students, temp service and term positions, supplies, service contracts, business travel, staff development, conferences, and any other non-PSR  expense needed to operate CTG UAlbany. CTG doesn’t receive an annual OTPS allocation from the Division of Research, instead it revenue generates on its own to support CTG’s OTPS budget.  A unique aspect of CTG’s financial/business model relative to most academic departments and other research units; is that CTG not only relies on its traditional research funded projects, but has many state agency projects, under state MOUs and revenue contracts. These state projects are a part of the strategic business development and financial planning that is the necessary support our annual operational budget. Within this template provided, it doesn’t allow a place for CTG UAlbany to report those state MOUs and Revenue contracts pending, as is the case for pending submitted RF proposals. Therefore, the information is provided here in the narrative.  CTG has several MOUs pending with state agencies such as: 1. NYS BOE’s Future elections at $310,000, 2. NYS BOE Election Remediation Risk at $35,000, along with several other opportunities in the business development, additional work on the project with the United Arab Emirates estimated at an additional $40K and new work with the United Nations for a round two which is in the business development stages. Also, we are submitting a preliminary proposal to IMLS related focused on exploring the role of public libraries as intermediaries of innovation in local and regional contexts.
